body: Can you do a git bisect to find out when the benchmark broke? Then we can see if it has always been broken or something specific we did broke it which we probably need to fix - thank you :-)

@ncw 

Some day in the past the Slash encode option was added to Onedrive encoder so it began to encode slashes in file names rather then treat them as path separators. Somebody forgot to adapt benchmark test cases in `lib/encoder` accordingly.

Here is patch to fix it: https://github.com/ivandeex/rclone/commit/996247e33ebe41e82f2b433385c012a551fe12de
I wrote it assuming that `TestX` test cases are authoritative and `BenchmarkX` were intended for a fix then forgotten, so I just put `got` into `want`.

Do you want it merged?

Now all two packages with benchmarks have it pass.
Running `go test -bench=. -run=Benchmark ./...`
produced https://github.com/rclone/rclone/files/7435966/benchmark.txt

#### Part II

Okay, This bug report is purely promotional.
I thought why not give it a try.

Opened https://github.com/marketplace/gobencher, accepted access to https://github.com/ivandeex/rclone,
pushed the commit above,
the CI job report is here https://github.com/ivandeex/rclone/actions/runs/1395533530

Found no traces of benchmark reports,
then looked at their "trending" site and found this:
https://dashboard.github.orijtech.com/benchmark/50fe847c6338439b8e1dbbbf00f020a9

**No. Benchmark. Results.** :O

I don't think I want to dig or go deeper

Anyway the trend is good - no errors anymore
https://dashboard.github.orijtech.com/?repo=ivandeex%2Frclone
ðŸ˜„

Thanks for trying out bencher, @ivandeex ! For the CI job report part, I believe the link you checked is for the GitHub Actions. The overall runs page, which includes both checks and actions seems to have bencher: https://github.com/ivandeex/rclone/runs/4037305887

The "No benchmark results" was definitely misleading UX on our part. What's actually happening is that the benchmark did complete with results, but there were no prior successful benchmarks on the base branch (master) to compare against. We've updated the UI to more accurately describe this situation (thanks for the feedback!). Once the change is merged to master, benchmarks for future commits will be able to show the benchmark's diff against the latest successful benchmark on master.

@ivandeex wrote:
> Some day in the past the Slash encode option was added to Onedrive encoder so it began to encode slashes in file names rather then treat them as path separators. Somebody forgot to adapt benchmark test cases in `lib/encoder` accordingly.

I expect that was me!

We don't run the benchmarks as part of the CI so that will be why it broke and we didn't notice.

> Here is patch to fix it: [ivandeex@996247e](https://github.com/ivandeex/rclone/commit/996247e33ebe41e82f2b433385c012a551fe12de) I wrote it assuming that `TestX` test cases are authoritative and `BenchmarkX` were intended for a fix then forgotten, so I just put `got` into `want`.
> 
> Do you want it merged?

Yes, I think that looks great - thanks.
 
> Now all two packages with benchmarks have it pass. Running `go test -bench=. -run=Benchmark ./...` produced https://github.com/rclone/rclone/files/7435966/benchmark.txt

:-)

Bencher looks interesting.

We don't have a lot of benchmarks in rclone only in `lib/encoder` and `lib/mmap` and just for those it probably isn't worth adding it.

Some more integration testy benchmarks would be useful, like copying a file to and from a :memory: backend - that might catch regressions the users care about. I wonder though, they would probably be quite variable depending on how heavily loaded the Actions runner was.

> Some more integration testy benchmarks would be useful

Benchmarks might be also useful for
- #5624 
- #5686

Not much. Rclone is mostly bound by network.

issue.title: lib/encoder: fix benchmarks

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
Some day in the past the Slash encode option was added to Onedrive
encoder so it began to encode slashes in file names rather then treat
them as path separators.
This patch adapts benchmark test cases accordingly.

Fixes #5659

body:
@kirbyquerby 

> the link you checked is for the GitHub Actions. The overall runs page

I admit I have problems using Github GUI to get from the CI actions page https://github.com/ivandeex/rclone/actions/runs/1395533530 though to checks https://github.com/ivandeex/rclone/runs/4037305887

I don't have a Checks tab for the repo and I can't find an enabler in the settings https://github.com/ivandeex/rclone/settings

I can't find help in your docs https://bencher.orijtech.com/starting/

On a 3rd party site https://circleci.com/docs/2.0/enable-checks/ they talk about `Checks` tab for a PR.
To verify that I'll need to do a pull request against my own repo. For now, I'm just looking if that 
can be done for a usual commit.

> What's actually happening is that the benchmark did complete with results, but there were no prior successful benchmarks on the base branch (master) to compare against.

After fixing the benchmark I repeated the commit with a different commit message. Now I have two commits with working benchmarks. Still nothing on the Bencher dashboard:
https://dashboard.github.orijtech.com/?repo=ivandeex%2Frclone

Maybe it's because we don't have benchmarks in the root source folder, only in a few subdirs?
I'm sure you can get it sorted.

P.S. Not a big deal for this particular project. As I told, rclone is rather bound by network i/o.

@ivandeex

> I admit I have problems using Github GUI to get from the CI actions page https://github.com/ivandeex/rclone/actions/runs/1395533530 though to checks https://github.com/ivandeex/rclone/runs/4037305887

Yeah, GitHub's UI is a bit weird in that respect -- unfortunately, while actions and checks behave somewhat similarly, they have some unintuitive differences. The  `Actions` tab of the repository only shows results from _actions_, not from _checks_. The way I got to your checks run from your commit was:
1. I visited the commit's page: https://github.com/ivandeex/rclone/commit/996247e33ebe41e82f2b433385c012a551fe12de
2. I clicked the little green check mark to the left of the commit title (if the checks are still running, it will be a yellow circle. Or if any checks failed, it will be a red X):
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6455350/139475175-57427856-698b-4612-bb0f-cdabc8473ffe.png)
3. This brought up a scrollable list of all of the checks and actions. At the bottom was bencher's check:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6455350/139475245-2099599d-d678-46fb-a4e0-c8169e9f640e.png)
4. I clicked the "details" link, which took me to https://github.com/ivandeex/rclone/runs/4037305887

On a PR, the information is surfaced a bit more easily, as the `Checks` tab shows both _checks_ and _actions_ (eg https://github.com/kirbyquerby/test-gobencher/pull/17/checks) . Unfortunately I'm not aware of a more obvious way to get to the checks page without making a PR. We can definitely update our documentation to show how to get to the benchmark results page from a commit.

> After fixing the benchmark I repeated the commit with a different commit message. Now I have two commits with working benchmarks. Still nothing on the Bencher dashboard:

The issue is that **there are no previous successful benchmarks on master** (the "base branch"), so we have nothing to compare against when showing benchmark results. Ordinarily, bencher would populate this itself but this step failed because the benchmarks on master currently fail:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6455350/139480269-20aa2d8c-018e-4a14-b62d-bf991dbb6606.png)

Once the change fixing the benchmarks is merged to master, new PRs/commits will have results, such as:
https://dashboard.github.orijtech.com/benchmark/5138fac076f244b5b7dbae8aa5c36305

Thanks again for the feedback, and please let me know if anything's still unclear.

I guess landing the "little green check" trick in your docs will help your future users.

Thanks, it's clear now.
